race.name: Reliance Deep Woods
race.tagline: Unmarked Cherokee National Forest gravel — just you, your GPS, and Tennessee mountains.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through TN mountains. Significant elevation with mountain/forest scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional TN event. Mountainous terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Reliance Deep Woods is a regional event in Tennessee—mountainous terrain with significant elevation. The TN mountain/forest scenery is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Tennessee provides good access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional TN gravel race with mountainous terrain. Worth it for TN/Southeast cyclists. Not a destination race for national travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in TN/Southeast and want a local mountain event—yes, it's solid. If you're from out of region—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar regional events: other TN gravel races. For better mountain events: NC/VA gravel races.

logistics.airport: Chattanooga (CHA) or Knoxville (TYS) depending on location
logistics.food: TN has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: Camping available with music, food, beer[1]

non_negotiables.why: TN mountain terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Single start at 155 Ellis Creek Road with 7:30 AM rollout keeps it simple, though course marking remains nonexistent. Carey Lowery witnessed navigation disasters firsthand: "Randy Kerr came riding up behind me. Apparently he had ridden the Piney Flats section twice instead of coming down Smith." Download your GPX or repeat sections accidentally.

length.explanation: The 66-mile Stage 1 with 9200 feet of climbing delivers proper suffer-fest territory, as Carey Lowery discovered: "Saturday's course was burly: 66 miles and 9200 feet." Stage 2 adds another 45 miles through terrain that had Jon Livengood logging "5:20 hrs on the bike and 338 TSS!" Multiple distance options let you choose your destruction level. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Jon Livengood summarizes the terrain perfectly: "many miles of climbs and descents where a mtb would (and did) shine. Basically the gravel turned to eroded dirt roads with endless embedded rock outcrops." Chunky double track dominates, with Carey noting "severely rutted out sections where you had to carefully pick your lines" after overnight rain. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The Wolf Creek-McFarland climb alone spans 10 miles with "horribly steep pitches, washed out road beds, and chonky bedrock to negotiate." Carey Lowery found the 3-mile Swinging Bridge climb "went by quickly," but Stage 2's final 20 miles featured "multiple 'Flanders steepness' hills...3-5 minute efforts on 15%+ grades" according to Jon Livengood. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 69°F and lows of 49°F, with a 47% chance of rain on any given day. Late April in east Tennessee mountains hits that sweet spot—cool enough for big climbing efforts, warm enough that you won't freeze on descents. Spring weather can be unpredictable but beats summer heat or winter misery. No historical weather disasters mentioned in the research. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Carey Lowery puts it: "Saturday's course was burly: 66 miles and 9200 feet. And with a good bit of chunky gravel/double track, my 2016 Niner RKT RDO with 2.2 Race Kings was the right bike for the gnar."

altitude.explanation: This is Tennessee, not Colorado. Cherokee National Forest elevations won't challenge your oxygen intake or require acclimatization. The climbing difficulty comes from gradient and distance, not thin air. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Cherokee National Forest delivers wilderness gravel with no course marking—just you, your GPS, and Tennessee mountains. Camping under the stars with live music and beer after destroying yourself on Buck Bald and Starr Mountain. This is proper gravel adventure, not sanitized corporate racing.

prestige.explanation: This is grassroots Tennessee gravel through and through—SORBA Chattanooga fundraiser with camping and beer, not UCI points. No notable past winners or pro field mentioned anywhere. It's a killer weekend in Cherokee National Forest that the locals love, but nobody's building their season around it.

race_quality.explanation: No course marking means you better download that GPX or you're lost in the Tennessee woods. Timing checkpoints at Buck Bald and Starr Mountain summits keep it legitimate, but the production values are clearly small-batch. When the research can't even pin down consistent distances or entry fees, you know what you're getting into.

experience.explanation: Cherokee National Forest delivers the goods—8700 feet of climbing on the long route through terrain that's definitely not champagne gravel. Saturday's 72-mile beast hits Buck Bald and Starr Mountain while Sunday serves up rockier punishment. The "beautiful country, great crowd, good times" testimonial tells you everything about the vibe.

community.explanation: Tennessee Gravel runs a proper grassroots weekend with camping, music, and beer at 155 Ellis Creek Road. SORBA Chattanooga gets the fundraising benefit while riders get that authentic gravel family feel. It's the kind of event where everyone knows each other by Sunday.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, field size unknown, no pro presence mentioned, and it's a regional Tennessee affair in late April. They offer three different Saturday distances suggests they're accommodating recreational riders more than attracting elite competition. Grassroots means grassroots talent level. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Jon Livengood puts it: "Managed to take 1st place in Masters and 5th overall for the race! And, as a podium bonus, we got podium HUGS! Basecamp Winter Program played a big role in ensuring I had a super solid foundation-stok..."

value.explanation: Two-day stage race format with camping included gives you solid weekend bang for your buck. Cherokee National Forest access, aid stations at mountain summits, and that authentic Tennessee gravel community experience. Entry fees aren't published but the grassroots nature suggests reasonable pricing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $75-125. Reliance, Tennessee location means driving for most riders, though on-site camping controls lodging costs. Carey's equipment choices—mountain bike for Stage 1's chunk, gravel bike with 45mm tires for Stage 2—suggest gear-conscious riders might want multiple setups. Remote Cherokee National Forest setting limits nearby amenities and convenience options. Higher total cost than Badlands.

unsplash_photos.description: a rock covered in snow next to a tree
a rock wall with moss growing on it
A large rock sits in a dense forest.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
